learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the major phases of historical European staging traditions and conventions and how they operate textually and performatively.
Recognise how shifting historical movements, especially in relation to science, sex, and the supernatural, interact with and are figured in dramatic and theatrical conventions and developments.
Comprehend the importance of political and social contexts, genre expectations, and specific spaces on audience reception of historical European theatre.
Understand the critical context (both then and now) for historical European theatre.
Recontextualise historical European theatre for a present-day audience through group performance.

assessments.due_date:
Week 2 - Week 12

NOTE: Participation is not assessed in week 10 due to the public holiday.
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
This task assesses your engagement with the course across the Semester. Each week, your engagement with your course content and the tutorial activity (weeks 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11) is worth 3%. For Week 10, which is a public holiday, you will receive your average participation mark for the semester.

For the first 2% of your participation mark, you will be assessed on the basis of three components: preparation for class; engagement with the learning activities in class; and respectful peer collaboration. You must bring a copy of the relevant text (e-copies are acceptable) and any additional material to every tutorial, and you must have read them at least once. Attendance itself is not sufficient to constitute 'participation'. Participation means willing involvement, active engagement with the text and the tasks at hand, asking questions, working well in groups, and demonstrating evidence of having listened to the lectures. To receive full marks, your tutor will need to see evidence of you having engaged with this full spectrum of activity.

For the final 1% of your weekly participation mark, you will complete one blackboard post of 100 words, responding to a specific prompt. Some Blackboard Entries will require responses to visual and/or audio-visual material. Blackboard submissions are due by the commencement of your seminar each week.

Acting ability is not assessed. It is your responsibility to ensure that your attendance has been recorded. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
In this Research Essay, you will demonstrate your acquired knowledge and research skills by writing about a contemporary realisation of one of the plays studied in this course. 

This task will assess your ability to:

  • answer (or produce) a relevant and compelling research question;
  • provide an analytic approach to the topic and its relevant issues;
  • construct a strong argument; and
  • provide evidence from one required text and secondary material to support this argument.

The referencing style used for Drama assignments is MLA, 9th edition.

A detailed assignment brief will be made available via Blackboard in due course.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will submit on Turnitin via Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
20/10/2025 - 20/10/2025

Performances will take place in regular tutorial hours.
assessments.task_description:
Working in groups, this task will invite you to produce a performance response to the three major themes of the course; that is, the relationship between science, sex and the supernatural, and how these are interrogated through the spatial conventions of the historical European theatrical tradition. Drawing on the texts that we have studied in the course, you will produce a performance of approximately ten minutes' duration. This performance may be staged in a non-traditional venue. This task invites you to respond to the course in an embodied way, while maintaining the critical and analytical rigour of your interrogation.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Recording of Oral and Practical Assessment

All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)

Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.

Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of:

  • Moderation of marking;
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction

This lecture will introduce the structure of the course, and discuss how staging superstition/ magic and anxiety around sex and gender roles shaped Early Modern theatrical culture via an exemplar text: The Tempest


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction This lecture will introduce the structure of the course, and discuss how staging superstition/ magic and anxiety around sex and gender roles shaped Early Modern theatrical culture via an exemplar text: The Tempest

learning_activities.topic: Week 1: NO TUTORIALS
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: NO TUTORIALS

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Outdoor Bodies

This lecture will use "As You Like It" to introduce various elements of Early Modern performance practice, especially as they relate to sex and gender.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Outdoor Bodies This lecture will use "As You Like It" to introduce various elements of Early Modern performance practice, especially as they relate to sex and gender.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Early-modern bodies

This tutorial will focus on staging (and interrogating) the various kinds of bodies required in Early Modern performance, particularly in relation to gendered bodies.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Early-modern bodies This tutorial will focus on staging (and interrogating) the various kinds of bodies required in Early Modern performance, particularly in relation to gendered bodies.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Outdoor sex

In this lecture, we use "Edward II" to think through how sex and gender roles were represented on the outdoor stage.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Outdoor sex In this lecture, we use "Edward II" to think through how sex and gender roles were represented on the outdoor stage.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Men

In this tutorial, we consider different models of maleness and masculinity in the Early Modern era, through the disruptive force of same-sex desire on stage.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Men In this tutorial, we consider different models of maleness and masculinity in the Early Modern era, through the disruptive force of same-sex desire on stage.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Staging the City

In this lecture, we position "The Alchemist" as part magic show and part City comedy to consider a more satirical position on magic in the indoor theatre.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Staging the City In this lecture, we position "The Alchemist" as part magic show and part City comedy to consider a more satirical position on magic in the indoor theatre.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: City/Country

In this tutorial, we look at how changing attitudes towards magic and science found expression in Jonson's satire.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: City/Country In this tutorial, we look at how changing attitudes towards magic and science found expression in Jonson's satire.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Outdoor Illusions

This lecture introduces our exploration of early attempts at meta-theatre, using the case study of Calderon de la Barca's "Life is a Dream" and its mixing of illusions and dreams.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Outdoor Illusions This lecture introduces our exploration of early attempts at meta-theatre, using the case study of Calderon de la Barca's "Life is a Dream" and its mixing of illusions and dreams.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Heroes

This tutorial will focus on the figure of the hero in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to Segismundo from Calderon's "Life is a Dream".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Heroes This tutorial will focus on the figure of the hero in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to Segismundo from Calderon's "Life is a Dream".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Indoor Illusions

This week's lecture introduces the figure of the sexual outlaw through Moliere's "Don Juan" in this iteration, in the form of a sexually voracious man and his supernatural comeuppance.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Indoor Illusions This week's lecture introduces the figure of the sexual outlaw through Moliere's "Don Juan" in this iteration, in the form of a sexually voracious man and his supernatural comeuppance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Outlaws

This tutorial will focus on agents of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to the sexual outlaw in "Don Juan".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Outlaws This tutorial will focus on agents of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to the sexual outlaw in "Don Juan".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Enter the Actress (1)

This week's lecture turns its attention a play that interrogates the gendered and sexualised expectations of the outlaw-figure, in Aphra Behn's "The Rover".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Enter the Actress (1) This week's lecture turns its attention a play that interrogates the gendered and sexualised expectations of the outlaw-figure, in Aphra Behn's "The Rover".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Women

In this tutorial, we consider women and the feminine allure as an agent of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, through the case study of Behn's "The Rover".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Women In this tutorial, we consider women and the feminine allure as an agent of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, through the case study of Behn's "The Rover".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Enter the Actress (2)

This lecture considers the male playwright's response to the arrival of women on- and off-stage, through the case study of William Congreve's "Love for Love" which helpfully also includes a mad, superstitious figure coded as male.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Enter the Actress (2) This lecture considers the male playwright's response to the arrival of women on- and off-stage, through the case study of William Congreve's "Love for Love" which helpfully also includes a mad, superstitious figure coded as male.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Women (2)

In this tutorial, we consider women and the feminine allure as an agent of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, through the case study of Congreve’s "Love for Love". Group allocations will also be finalised for the Group Performance Project.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Women (2) In this tutorial, we consider women and the feminine allure as an agent of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, through the case study of Congreve’s "Love for Love". Group allocations will also be finalised for the Group Performance Project.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Triumph of Reason (1)

In this week's lecture, we begin our conclusion of this period of theatre history by considering a play that depicts the triumph of reason, Marivaux's "The Dispute".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Triumph of Reason (1) In this week's lecture, we begin our conclusion of this period of theatre history by considering a play that depicts the triumph of reason, Marivaux's "The Dispute".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Rehearsals

This tutorial will begin rehearsals for the Group Performance Project task. Out-of-class rehearsals can be scheduled across the following fortnight.

Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Rehearsals This tutorial will begin rehearsals for the Group Performance Project task. Out-of-class rehearsals can be scheduled across the following fortnight.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Triumph of Reason (2)

In this final lecture, we look at a play that moves from the excess Sturm und Drang movement into the reason and order of Romanticism, Schiller's "Mary Stuart".

Please note this lecture will be pre-recorded due to falling on a public holiday.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Triumph of Reason (2) In this final lecture, we look at a play that moves from the excess Sturm und Drang movement into the reason and order of Romanticism, Schiller's "Mary Stuart". Please note this lecture will be pre-recorded due to falling on a public holiday.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Rehearsals

This tutorial will be used for rehearsals for the upcoming Group Performance Project.

As the regular tutorial time falls on a public holiday, students will instead book supervised rehearsal time with the drama technician for their upcoming group performance project on an alternate date in Week 11. Bookable dates and times will be communicated during semester via Blackboard.

Learning outcomes: L05
